newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: TENNIS-CHANG BEATS SAMPRAS IN OPEN REHEARSAL.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-CHANG BEATS SAMPRAS IN OPEN REHEARSAL.

text.p: American Michael Chang gave himself a psychological edge over world number one Pete Sampras on Saturday by winning a key warm-up event before the Australian Open for the third year in succession.
Chang, the world number two and second seed at the Open, starting on Monday, defeated compatriot Sampras 4-6 6-4 6-2 in one hour and 35 minutes in the Colonial Classic in Kooyong.

A losing finalist to Boris Becker in Melbourne last year, Chang is convinced he can finally take the extra step required to add a second grand slam title to his French Open success as a teenager in 1989.
"If there is one word that sums up my career, it would be perseverance," said Chang, who also reached last year's U.S. Open final only to lose to Sampras.
"Over the past couple of years I have got to a lot of finals and come up short. I have just had to pick myself up and try, try again," Chang said.

"I feel physically and mentally ready -- now we'll have to see what the next two weeks have in store," said Chang, who produced a typically tenacious performance on Saturday, highlighting the qualities that have lifted him to his current ranking, the highest of his career.
After losing the first set in hot, blustery conditions, the 24-year-old Chang refused to yield to his great rival before eventually dominating the third and final set.
Chang will play Belgium's Kris Goossen, a lucky loser ranked 132 in the world, in the first round of the Open at the National Tennis Centre.
Sampras also declared himself satisfied with his preparations for the first grand slam tournament of the year.
"This has been good preparation for me and I feel fit and fresh for next week," said Sampras, who is scheduled to meet Chang in the Open final on January 26 according to the seedings.
"Michael is always difficult to play," Sampras told reporters. "But it's a long time until the final and that is the last thing on my mind at the moment."
Sampras will begin his challenge for a second Australian Open and ninth grand slam title in total against Romanian qualifier Dinu Pescariu, ranked 169 in the world.
